CatDescriptText: Image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, November 16, 1946, pg. 3, in "Public Opinion" column, with question: "The Courier's Inquiring Reporter, on a brief tour of Hill District bars this week, found that local mixologists of color, had mixed feelings when approached with the question: 'Do you think that local Negro bartenders should affiliate themselves with organized labor?" Image cutline reads: "Bill Ballard, 516 Perry Street, Yellin's Wylie Avenue at Erin Street: 'When we tried to do it before, we couldn't get in.  They didn't want us, excepting as waiters, bell-hops, etc. I don't think we should affiliate ourselves with labor.  That's all I have to say regarding the subject.'"
TitMainTitle: Portrait of bartender Bill Ballard posed with hands resting on bar, in front of cash register rung to $ .15, sign reading "Please pay when served," and advertisement for Red Cap ale, in Yellin's Bar on Wylie Avenue
